<https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/14671/files|6db9601>: Support asymmetric rolling rollbacks
Improve the rolling updater rollback/abort function by making it aware
of the original replicas annotation: if the rollback target has the
original replica count recorded, prefer it over the desired annotation
since the update from old to new could have been asymmetrical.

For example, when scaling from 5 to 10, aborting should scale back to 5. - ironcladlou

<https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/14706/files|4309caf>: rkt: return non error if the pod doesn't exist in GetPodStatus().
Previously, GetPodStatus() will return error if the pod is never
created. However we've never seen the sync loop fail because in the
beginning of the loop, if the pod is not found, it will be created.

This works fine except the pod that keeps crashing. Because the above
logic will keep restarting the pod as if it's never created.

This PR fixes the bug. - yifan-gu
4292/4310 tests passed

<https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/14706/files|4309caf>: rkt: return non error if the pod doesn't exist in GetPodStatus().
Previously, GetPodStatus() will return error if the pod is never
created. However we've never seen the sync loop fail because in the
beginning of the loop, if the pod is not found, it will be created.

This works fine except the pod that keeps crashing. Because the above
logic will keep restarting the pod as if it's never created.

This PR fixes the bug. - yifan-gu

<https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/14671/files|6db9601>: Support asymmetric rolling rollbacks
Improve the rolling updater rollback/abort function by making it aware
of the original replicas annotation: if the rollback target has the
original replica count recorded, prefer it over the desired annotation
since the update from old to new could have been asymmetrical.

For example, when scaling from 5 to 10, aborting should scale back to 5. - ironcladlou

<https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/14671/files|6db9601>: Support asymmetric rolling rollbacks
Improve the rolling updater rollback/abort function by making it aware
of the original replicas annotation: if the rollback target has the
original replica count recorded, prefer it over the desired annotation
since the update from old to new could have been asymmetrical.

For example, when scaling from 5 to 10, aborting should scale back to 5. - ironcladlou

<https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/14706/files|4309caf>: rkt: return non error if the pod doesn't exist in GetPodStatus().
Previously, GetPodStatus() will return error if the pod is never
created. However we've never seen the sync loop fail because in the
beginning of the loop, if the pod is not found, it will be created.

This works fine except the pod that keeps crashing. Because the above
logic will keep restarting the pod as if it's never created.

This PR fixes the bug. - yifan-gu

<https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/14566/files|122a9a4>: Improve jobs e2e
Remove unnecessary yaml file.

Define 4 specific pod behaviors.
(sleeping for short periods is going to be flaky during automated
testing.  Also, sleep -1 still exits 0)

Don't wait for a certain number of active pods in tests
where the pods terminate after a finite time, since this is racy.

Changed some tests to use pods that run forever, and not wait
for completion.

Added tests with local restarts.

Convert the DeleteOptions to the correct api group. - erictune
4292/4310 tests passed

<https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/14671/files|498c2e4>: Support asymmetric rolling rollbacks
Improve the rolling updater rollback/abort function by making it aware
of the original replicas annotation: if the rollback target has the
original replica count recorded, prefer it over the desired annotation
since the update from old to new could have been asymmetrical.

For example, when scaling from 5 to 10, aborting should scale back to 5. - ironcladlou

Mon Sep 28 2015 12:38:39 GMT+0000 (UTC)
<https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/13658/files|945a1ff>: Allow AWS region and endpoint to be configured
The aws-sdk-go supports custom endpoints and regions for EC2 compatible clouds.
This change allows to configure a region and endpoint in the aws cloud provider
config. These parameters are passed through to the aws client.

Coincidentally, this also leads to the region validation to fail if
the EC2 compatible cloud is, well not, 100% compatible and doesn't adhere to
the Amazons naming scheme. The assumption is that the region can be calculated
by striping the index of the availability zone. Since this is not always the
case, an explicit region in the config will not be validated. - BugRoger
 No test results were reported.

<https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/14618/files|702f73f>: Refactor exec to make attach useful without a client.Config
The current executor structure is too dependent on client.Request
and client.Config. In order to do an attach from the server, it needs
to be possible to create an Executor from crypto/tls#TLSConfig and to
bypassing having a client.Request.

Changes:

* remotecommand.spdyExecutor - handles upgrading a request to SPDY and getting a connection
* remotecommand.NewAttach / New - moved to exec / portforward / attach since they handle requests
* Remove request.Upgrade() - it's too coupled to SPDY, and can live with the spdyExecutor
* Add request.VersionedParams(runtime.Object, runtime.ObjectConvertor) to handle object -> query transform - smarterclayton

Sat Sep 26 2015 21:47:11 GMT+0000 (UTC)
<https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/14614/files|6774690>: Deleting gracefully terminating, not-scheduled pre-scheduled pods
In upstream the kubelet is responsible for all pods which have the spec.NodeName
set. In Mesos we have a two-stage scheduling process:

1. pods with a pre-set spec.NodeName are still scheduled by the scheduler.
2. The kubelet will only see them when a Mesos task was started and the executor
   passes the pod to the kubelet.

With this PR a pod with spec.NodeName which is gracefully terminated, but not
yet scheduled, e.g.

- because the termination happened just after creation and the scheduler was
  not fast enough
- because the NodeSelector does not match

is deleted by the Mesos scheduler. - sttts
4292/4310 tests passed

Sat Sep 26 2015 15:46:17 GMT+0000 (UTC)
<https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/13885/files|9db07cb>: Expose exec and logs via WebSockets
Not all clients and systems can support SPDY protocols. This commit adds
support for two new websocket protocols, one to handle streaming of pod
logs from a pod, and the other to allow exec to be tunneled over
websocket.

Browser support for chunked encoding is still poor, and web consoles
that wish to show pod logs may need to make compromises to display the
output. The /pods/<name>/log endpoint now supports websocket upgrade to
the '<http://binary.k8s.io|binary.k8s.io>' subprotocol, which sends chunks of logs as binary to
the client. Messages are written as logs are streamed from the container
daemon, so flushing should be unaffected.

Browser support for raw communication over SDPY is not possible, and
some languages lack libraries for it and HTTP/2. The Kubelet supports
upgrade to WebSocket instead of SPDY, and will multiplex STDOUT/IN/ERR
over websockets by prepending each binary message with a single byte
representing the channel (0 for IN, 1 for OUT, and 2 for ERR). Because
framing on WebSockets suffers from head-of-line blocking, clients and
other server code should ensure that no particular stream blocks. An
alternative subprotocol '<http://base64.channel.k8s.io|base64.channel.k8s.io>' base64 encodes the body
and uses '0'-'9' to represent the channel for ease of use in browsers. - smarterclayton
4308/4326 tests passed

<https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/14566/files|7002a48>: Improve jobs e2e
Remove unnecessary yaml file.

Define 4 specific pod behaviors.
(sleeping for short periods is going to be flaky during automated
testing.  Also, sleep -1 still exits 0)

Don't wait for a certain number of active pods in tests
where the pods terminate after a finite time, since this is racy.

Changed some tests to use pods that run forever, and not wait
for completion.

Added tests with local restarts.

Convert the DeleteOptions to the correct api group. - erictune

Sat Sep 26 2015 01:15:45 GMT+0000 (UTC)
<https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/13885/files|86a6add>: Expose exec and logs via WebSockets
Not all clients and systems can support SPDY protocols. This commit adds
support for two new websocket protocols, one to handle streaming of pod
logs from a pod, and the other to allow exec to be tunneled over
websocket.

Browser support for chunked encoding is still poor, and web consoles
that wish to show pod logs may need to make compromises to display the
output. The /pods/<name>/log endpoint now supports websocket upgrade to
the '<http://binary.k8s.io|binary.k8s.io>' subprotocol, which sends chunks of logs as binary to
the client. Messages are written as logs are streamed from the container
daemon, so flushing should be unaffected.

Browser support for raw communication over SDPY is not possible, and
some languages lack libraries for it and HTTP/2. The Kubelet supports
upgrade to WebSocket instead of SPDY, and will multiplex STDOUT/IN/ERR
over websockets by prepending each binary message with a single byte
representing the channel (0 for IN, 1 for OUT, and 2 for ERR). Because
framing on WebSockets suffers from head-of-line blocking, clients and
other server code should ensure that no particular stream blocks. An
alternative subprotocol '<http://base64.channel.k8s.io|base64.channel.k8s.io>' base64 encodes the body
and uses '0'-'9' to represent the channel for ease of use in browsers. - smarterclayton
4310/4328 tests passed

<https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/13885/files|86a6add>: Expose exec and logs via WebSockets
Not all clients and systems can support SPDY protocols. This commit adds
support for two new websocket protocols, one to handle streaming of pod
logs from a pod, and the other to allow exec to be tunneled over
websocket.

Browser support for chunked encoding is still poor, and web consoles
that wish to show pod logs may need to make compromises to display the
output. The /pods/<name>/log endpoint now supports websocket upgrade to
the '<http://binary.k8s.io|binary.k8s.io>' subprotocol, which sends chunks of logs as binary to
the client. Messages are written as logs are streamed from the container
daemon, so flushing should be unaffected.

Browser support for raw communication over SDPY is not possible, and
some languages lack libraries for it and HTTP/2. The Kubelet supports
upgrade to WebSocket instead of SPDY, and will multiplex STDOUT/IN/ERR
over websockets by prepending each binary message with a single byte
representing the channel (0 for IN, 1 for OUT, and 2 for ERR). Because
framing on WebSockets suffers from head-of-line blocking, clients and
other server code should ensure that no particular stream blocks. An
alternative subprotocol '<http://base64.channel.k8s.io|base64.channel.k8s.io>' base64 encodes the body
and uses '0'-'9' to represent the channel for ease of use in browsers. - smarterclayton

<https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/14566/files|eb6f6a2>: Improve jobs e2e
Remove unnecessary yaml file.

Define 4 specific pod behaviors.
(sleeping for short periods is going to be flaky during automated
testing.  Also, sleep -1 still exits 0)

Don't wait for a certain number of active pods in tests
where the pods terminate after a finite time, since this is racy.

Changed some tests to use pods that run forever, and not wait
for completion.

Added tests with local restarts.

Convert the DeleteOptions to the correct api group. - erictune
4264/4283 tests passed

Remove unnecessary yaml file.

Define 4 specific pod behaviors.
(sleeping for short periods is going to be flaky during automated
testing.  Also, sleep -1 still exits 0)

Don't wait for a certain number of active pods in tests

for completion.

Added tests with local restarts.

Convert the DeleteOptions to the correct api group. - erictune

text: <@U3S8A0RP0> It's hard to understand what exactly you are asking me. I don't work for Hashicorp and I'm not trying to push their product, only explain what it does on top of encrypted KV storage.

Thx <@U21PD486R>

Vault generates new secrets, it doesn't just store them. So it acts as an authentication hub; you can use public key auth to get a temporary database password, or a bearer token to get a TLS server certificate, and so on.
<@U45JX5RPA> ok, so we use JWT and have all of the authnz already.
share secrets with services outside of k8s maybe ?
thanks <@U3S8A0RP0>, i've exactly the same question as yours. What would be the value of vault ? I don't see it clearly to be honest.
not k8s related more than the microservice is gonna run in the cluster
it will most likely be used for a auth backend that our developers are writing
<@U45JX5RPA> what value do you see from using it? Do you have a different trust boundary then I have?
basicly i had to modify a line of systems including our internal DNS to pass requests for the consul domain to the consul dns servers
and this was a fully redundant HA setup
with no experience of the components i clocked in around 30 hours of work for a consul + vault cluster with the possibility to remote unseal and basic health checks in place
you need a fully functioning consul cluster and you need to use it’s DNS service to resolve the active vault service etc
i deployed vault as a stand alone service and that in itself was a adenture

Many people seem to use vault, we do not, right now. Mostly we do not do it because of the additional complexity and maintenance, and right now I don't really see the point of having the trust boundary inside of the cluster. If you can connect from via service type clusterIP without authnz, then it's not worth, in my opinion. Maybe I just don't see the attack vector, but people can try to convince me.
<@U0F45L9PD> it depends where you draw the line of trust

Hello gentle folks. I hope I am at the right place to ask my fancy question. I am wondering about how the communication design between an operator and its resources should look like. So far we are used to do communication in one direction, which is from the operator to the managed resource. How should it look like in case the managed resource wants to talk back to the operator? E.g. I am thinking about an operator that manages pods in a specific way. In case the pods are restarted or rescheduled I want the operator to know about it. There is now some lifecycle hook support for pods which would be a native entrypoint in this case. I am just wondering what the hook should do. Should it talk to an HTTP API the operator provides or should it update some annotation of the pod itself and the operator has to watch this? I am a bit puzzled on that. WDYT? 

Update: please answer in a thread.

text: <@U2QQSJZEF> <https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/workloads/controllers/cron-jobs/>

```
apiVersion: batch/v2alpha1
kind: CronJob
metadata:
  name: kube-gelf-reload-config
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  successfulJobsHistoryLimit: 1
  failedJobsHistoryLimit: 1
  schedule: “*/30 * * * *”
  jobTemplate:
    spec:
      template:
        spec:
          serviceAccountName: kube-gelf
          containers:
          - name: cron
            image: <http://gcr.io/google_containers/hyperkube-amd64:v1.7.5|gcr.io/google_containers/hyperkube-amd64:v1.7.5>
            args:
            - /bin/sh
            - -c
            - for POD in `kubectl get pod --namespace kube-system -l app=kube-gelf | tail -n +2 | awk '{print $1}'`; do echo RELOAD ${POD}; kubectl exec --namespace kube-system ${POD} -- /bin/sh -c ‘kill -1 1’; done
          restartPolicy: OnFailure
```

text:
<@U0B2WM5PT> Records read from the journal are initially tagged with 'journal' <https://github.com/openshift/origin-aggregated-logging/blob/master/fluentd/generate_throttle_configs.rb#L134>

These records are then retagged, primarily for kubernetes processing: <https://github.com/openshift/origin-aggregated-logging/blob/master/fluentd/configs.d/openshift/filter-retag-journal.conf>
If this is a record from journal, which is not from a container, then it will be retagged with 'journal.system': <https://github.com/openshift/origin-aggregated-logging/blob/master/fluentd/configs.d/openshift/filter-retag-journal.conf#L75>

# not kubernetes - assume a system log
  rewriterule9 _TRANSPORT .+ journal.system

so you probably want to have something like this:

   <match journal.system>
      @type rewrite_tag_filter
      rewriterule1 _SYSTEMD_UNIT ^origin-master.service journal.system.kubernetes.master
      rewriterule2 _SYSTEMD_UNIT ^origin-node.service journal.system.kubernetes.node
      rewriterule3 _TRANSPORT .+ journal.system # there is no default rule, and there is no way to say "no match, just pass through" - you have to match and rewrite _everything_ unfortunately

text: <@U0E40F05R> <@U5TFNBM42> <https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/44344>

It looks to me like there is a circular dependency in kops.  The internal components are configured to reach the k8s apiserver at `<http://api.internal.mycluster.com|api.internal.mycluster.com>`.  That is resolved by kube’s DNS application, which runs in pods after the kubelets and kube-proxy are up.  But the kubelets and kube-proxy need that domain name working before they can come up.

Yeah, we had to do something hairy like that a little while back, we basically just got our yaml manifests ready, mashed the apply command and cut over very shortly afterwards. I don’t think there’s much of a better way at the moment.

Biggest issue for us will be that we've got dozens of services, some that pull from things like kafka, or s3, before passing the data on. So they may not be able to be instantiated long before a cutover. Ideally our clusters would be able to live in isolation and then be "active" only when pointed to. But unfortunately we're not there yet.
Most of my migrations have been easy because all persistent datasources are external to our cluster. We just spin up new k8s, run our workloads, and point DNS

for roles, it still just checks if you already have all the RBAC permissions of the role you are creating/updating, with no fallback to ask the current authorizer if you have permission (since there's not a succinct way to ask the authorizer about potentially dozens of different permissions at once)

for role bindings, it checks if you already have all the RBAC permissions of the role you are binding to, OR if the current authorizer lets you perform the "bind" operation on the referenced role (so that would actually be allowed with the AlwaysAllow authorizer running)

<@U22V7T7HR> aww…no remote? :slightly_smiling_face:

those kind of tests say nothing…you can simply ask questions related to the person experience in the CV.
Give them hypothetical situations and see how he/she reacts and what is his/hers thought process
Ask normal kubernetes questions:
 - How do you deploy a cluster?
 - What is the difference between a pod and a node and a container? (you will be amazed how many people claim to use k8s but have no idea what is the difference)
 - What is a ConfigMap?
 - How are the secrets encrypted ? Is it safe for let’s say a public cluster?
 - What k8s version have you deployed?
 - how big was the cluster you maintained?
 - What kind of automation have you used to deploy k8s and why?
 - Selfhosted k8s or run it as a service? Why?
 - Selfhosted etcd or standalone cluster? What if we want to have cross DC failover?
 - Ansible vs Puppet/Chef/SaltStack
 - Terraform vs Ansible/Puppet/Chef/Puppet/SaltStack
 - Container vs Vm
 - When DNS traffic is not UDP?
 - How would you update from k8s 1.5 to 1.8?

We’re looking for a Staff/Senior Staff Support Engineer to help us grow and build our troubleshooting and support capabilities related to our enterprise offering, Tectonic. Thank you for the link, <@U7TEUTUMU>.  Important to note is that the probationary period is a two-party event.  For employees, if a company cannot determine your trustworthiness quickly, and you feel, as an individual under evaluation, that it’s not a good fit, consider that strongly if/when the period completes.  For employers, if you struggle to get organic buy-in from the majority of your contributors, remote or otherwise, you may need to analyze your incentives (they may not always be obvious).  Changing culture is hard from both ends; yet we collectively work in the cloud, which by definition, is a time, not a place.

attachments.fallback: wikipedia: Telecommuting
attachments.text:
Telecommuting, also called remote work, telework, or teleworking, is a work arrangement in which employees do not commute or travel (e.g. by bus or car) to a central place of work, such as an office building, warehouse, or store. Teleworkers in the 21st century often use mobile telecommunications technology such as Wi-Fi-equipped laptop or tablet computers and smartphones to work from coffee shops; others may use a desktop computer and a landline phone at their home. According to a Reuters poll, approximately "one in five workers around the globe, particularly employees in the Middle East, Latin America and Asia, telecommute frequently and nearly 10 percent work from home every day." In the 2000s, annual leave or vacation in some organizations is seen as absence from the workplace rather than ceasing work, and some office employees use telework to continue to check work e-mails while on vacation.
Although the concepts of "telecommuting" and "telework" are closely related, there is a difference between the two. All types of technology-assisted work conducted outside a centrally located work space (including work undertaken in the home, outside calls, etc.) are regarded as telework. Telecommuters often maintain a traditional office and usually work from an alternative work site from 1 to 3 days a week. Telecommuting refers more specifically to work undertaken at a location that reduces commuting time. These locations can be inside the home or at some other remote workplace, which is facilitated through a broadband connection, computer or phone lines, or any other electronic media used to interact and communicate. As a broader concept than telecommuting, telework has four dimensions in its definitional framework: work location, that can be anywhere outside a centralized organizational work place; usage of ICTs (information and communication technologies) as technical support for telework; time distribution, referring to the amount of time replaced in the traditional workplace; and the diversity of employment relationships between employer and employee, ranging from contract work to traditional full-time employment.
In the 1990s, telecommuting became the subject of pop culture attention. In 1995, the motto that "work is something you do, not something you travel to" was coined. Variations of this motto include: "Work is something we DO, not a place that we GO" and "Work is what we do, not where we are." Telecommuting has been adopted by a range of businesses, governments and not-for-profit organizations. Organizations may use telecommuting to reduce costs (telecommuting employees do not require an office or cubicle, a space which has to be rented or purchased, provided with lighting and climate control, etc.). Some organizations adopt telecommuting to improve workers' quality of life, as teleworking typically reduces commuting time and time stuck in traffic jams. As well, teleworking may make it easier for workers to balance their work responsibilities with family roles (e.g., caring for children or elderly parents). Some organizations adopt teleworking for environmental reasons, as telework can reduce congestion and air pollution, as it can reduce the number of cars on the roads.

attachments.fallback: Platform Operations Engineer - Paid Relocation (Kubernetes / Docker)
attachments.text: At Sky Betting & Gaming we don’t have Teams we have Tribes. Each Tribe is made up of small, agile and autonomous squads who work collaboratively with a shared purpose. So whether you join our Bet Tribe, Early Careers Tribe or anything in between, you will work with a group of people with raw energy, natural talent, and the kind of spirit that helps us think big, act bold, and change the game. It all means that we’ve created the kind of workplace that wins awards such as a place on the prestigious list of Sunday Times 100 Best Companies to Work For. What you’ll do: You will develop, operate, and evolve the Bet Tribe’s next-generation platform, based on Kubernetes, enabling internal teams to evolving their software and services with the minimum of friction.  You will also help teams to use various services on the platform, including deployment pipelines, service discovery, monitoring and alerting tools etc.  How you’ll do it: Required: Kubernetes Experience of Docker in production Networking AWS Linux operations Git Jenkins or similar CI system Beneficial: ElasticSearch or similar for log aggregation Operating high-scaled websites Multi-team development environment Regulated environments Consul or similar for service discovery  Prometheus, graphite, or similar for monitoring and alerting How we work: Our engineers work closely with colleagues in all positions, so a high level of interpersonal skill is important to us.   We are supporting squads running their apps in containers on Kubernetes.  This is a new platform for SB&G, so working with other teams to learn pros/cons etc is important. We use various agile techniques; you must be comfortable either working through tasks on your own, or collaborating with others. You will need to demonstrate good levels of skill in some of the following: Linux sysadmin, networking, containers, AWS, VMWare.   We expect candidates to be comfortable working in a highly technical environment, with various regulatory concerns.   We value previous experience developing and operating high-demand & high-availability environments.   Our ‘10% time’ policy means Friday afternoons are your time to remain at the top of your game.    We also offer an attractive relocation package for candidates that live outside the Yorkshire region, including those outside the UK. . Based in Yorkshire, we have grown to become one of the UK’s leading online betting and gaming companies. A business driven by bleeding edge technology, that brings the excitement of sports betting, casino games, poker and bingo to over 700,000 customers a day & growing! It’s a workplace like no other, with a mission to make Betting & Gaming better. And we want you to be part of it. Our People Ambition is to attract & develop diverse & talented people to meet the current and future growth needs of SB&G. Together, our aim is to create the Best Digital Business to work at. Mon to Fri – Standard

attachments.fallback: Heptio - Engineering Manager, Systems Software
attachments.text: Heptio is a Seattle startup in the systems infrastructure space. Our mission is to make mainstream enterprise more efficient in how they build teams and use physical resources. Our approach combines the what we learned at Google and other first tier software companies, with our experiences working with an empowered open source ecosystem. While at Google, the Heptio founders (Craig McLuckie and Joe Beda) started an open source project called Kubernetes. Kubernetes is a "container orchestrator" that enables IT organizations to offer API driven services to their organization along with drive up resource utilization. It is also a fast-growing open source community and the "seed crystal" for a groundbreaking set of technologies. While the founding team is based in Seattle, Heptio is building a company that fully supports distributed teams. attachments.fallback: Site Reliability Engineer (ID Analytics)
attachments.text: ID Analytics is a small company with a big impact on the ongoing effort to protect consumers and enterprises from fraudulent transactions.  Our platform predominantly runs on Linux, and we are seeking individuals to join our Site Reliability Engineering team to help us manage, deploy, and improve the reliability our products. A candidate that is a good fit will be a generalist - do you feel very comfortable working with Linux? Are you able to look at stack traces and source code of languages you may not have experience with and get a general idea of what is wrong?  Are you passionate about learning new technologies such as Docker and Kubernetes? Does the thought of writing Ansible or Go code excite you? We are looking for enthusiastic candidates that are eager to learn and grow their career. As a Site Reliability Engineer, you’ll be responsible for: • Write automation to patch systems for vulnerabilities • Troubleshoot issues with our products • Assist internal ID Analytics users with Linux issues and questions • Work directly with Engineering to improve the performance, stability, and availability of ID Analytics products. • Participate in off-hour on-call rotating support schedule for production systems.  Must be willing to carry phone and email device 24x7 to handle emergencies. • Other duties as required. Qualifications • Bachelor’s Degree, or demonstrable ability to perform the work required. • 0-2 years – should have basic knowledge of Linux and coding in Python or Go • Ability to succeed in a fast-paced agile/scrum environment. • Ability to troubleshoot and solve technical issues. • Excellent communication (both oral and written), organizational, and customer service skills. • Ability to protect all forms of highly confidential and proprietary business information and ability to maintain the highest standards of privacy and security. • Ability to follow and abide by all information and security policies and practices. ID Analytics is a leader in credit and fraud risk solutions with patented analytics, proven expertise and up-to-the-minute insight into consumer behavior. Founded in 2002, with a vision to think differently about how institutions solve the problem of verifying consumers’ identities, we now solve a full range of identity challenges, including assessing credit risk and improving online customer experience. Our tools help our clients protect themselves and their customers from identity risk and fraud. Our solutions are all powered by analytics, but it’s our access to data unseen by other bureaus that differentiates our solutions.  ID Analytics is a Symantec company. ====================​====================​ Symantec is an equal opportunity employer. All candidates for employment will be considered without regard to race, color, religion, sex, gender identity, sexual orientation, national origin, physical or mental disability, veteran status, or any other basis protected by applicable federal, state or local law.

attachments.fallback: Platform Operations Engineer
attachments.text: At Sky Betting & Gaming we don’t have Teams we have Tribes. Each Tribe is made up of small, agile and autonomous squads who work collaboratively with a shared purpose. So whether you join our Bet Tribe, Early Careers Tribe or anything in between, you will work with a group of people with raw energy, natural talent, and the kind of spirit that helps us think big, act bold, and change the game. It all means that we’ve created the kind of workplace that wins awards such as a place on the prestigious list of Sunday Times 100 Best Companies to Work For. What you’ll do: You will develop, operate, and evolve the Bet Tribe’s next-generation platform, based on Kubernetes, enabling internal teams to evolving their software and services with the minimum of friction.  You will also help teams to use various services on the platform, including deployment pipelines, service discovery, monitoring and alerting tools etc.  How you’ll do it: Required: Experience of Docker in production Networking AWS Linux operations Git Jenkins or similar CI system Beneficial: Kubernetes or similar platforms • Prometheus, graphite, or similar for monitoring and alerting ElasticSearch or similar for log aggregation Operating high-scaled websites Multi-team development environment Regulated environments Consul or similar for service discovery  How we work: Our engineers work closely with colleagues in all positions, so a high level of interpersonal skill is important to us.   We are supporting squads running their apps in containers on Kubernetes.  This is a new platform for SB&G, so working with other teams to learn pros/cons etc is important. We use various agile techniques; you must be comfortable either working through tasks on your own, or collaborating with others. You will need to demonstrate good levels of skill in some of the following: Linux sysadmin, networking, containers, AWS, VMWare.   We expect candidates to be comfortable working in a highly technical environment, with various regulatory concerns.   We value previous experience developing and operating high-demand & high-availability environments.   Our ‘10% time’ policy means Friday afternoons are your time to remain at the top of your game.    We will consider remote working (with at least 50% of time being in the base office), part-time working and flexible hours to accommodate your personal circumstances, providing we can meet our business needs. We also offer an attractive relocation package for candidates that live outside the Yorkshire region, including those outside the UK. . Based in Yorkshire, we have grown to become one of the UK’s leading online betting and gaming companies. A business driven by bleeding edge technology, that brings the excitement of sports betting, casino games, poker and bingo to over 200,000 customers a day & growing! It’s a workplace like no other, with a mission to make Betting & Gaming better. And we want you to be part of it. Our People Ambition is to attract & develop diverse & talented people to meet the current and future growth needs of SB&G. Together, our aim is to create the Best Digital Business to work at. Mon to Fri – Standard

attachments.fallback: Kubernetes Trainer at Kubernauts
attachments.text: About the Kubernetes Trainer position We are looking for a Kubernetes Trainer who&#39;d like to join our team at <http://kubernauts.io|kubernauts.io> as a Kubernetes Engineer or a Kubernetes Developer Advocate to develop technical training programs and train others in the Cloud-Native community to develop skills that would help them to become a Kubernaut and a Cloud-Native Thinker and Strategist. You should love mentoring people and sharing your knowledge with your peers and be extremely knowledgeable in the Cloud-Native field. It is also required to be an excellent communicator, able to explain complex subjects in a clear and interesting way and placing yourself in the position of being a user. Kubernetes Trainer responsibilities are: Create and review technical training programs according to our community requirements Prepare training schedules, classroom agenda and training materials, such as presentations, worksheets and so on Develop course content according to objectives Perform training sessions, webinars, workshops etc. in groups or individually Perform and conduct on-site training when needed Manage data on completed courses, absences, issues etc. Monitor and analyze results of training programs Evaluate overall effectiveness of programs and make improvements You are willing to travel for business purposes Kubernetes Trainer requirements are: 1+ years&#39; experience of working on a Technical Trainer position Significant experience in designing technical course content Excellent knowledge of modern training techniques and tools in technical subjects Good experience of addressing training needs with complete courses Strong communication skills and comfortable speaking to crowds Strong organizational and time-management abilities Degree in a relevant technical field; additional certification such as CKA (Certified Kubernetes Administrator, coming soon) will be a bonus It would be nice if ... You are an active open source advocate and cloud-native community lover You&#39;d love to code in Golang and contribute your work to Kubernetes community You&#39;ve experience with Docker Swarm, DC/OS, Cloud Foundry, OpenStack, CloudStack, AWS, GCP or Azure

Hi everyone,

We have an opening for a Kubernetes SME to work with us here at Contino (<http://www.contino.io|www.contino.io>).

12 week initial engagement in Germany. 

In short; his project is about enabling AWS consumption using automation and also helping with Kubernetes PaaS using giantswarm.

A key initiative in achieving efficiency and speed in the SDLC is our customers platform. This is a cloud based 'Platform As A Service' which makes it simpler and faster to develop digital consumer facing applications.

We are engaged as an advisory and delivery partner to support the build of the platforms initiative. This would involve contributing to the build of the platform best practices for automation and operability, but also support on-boarding onto the platform whilst also up-skilling and training our customers staff in parallel.

We are tasked with developing an internal AWS capability and remove the reliance on a third party vendor. We are also tasked with looking to teach our customer to understand AWS best practices, using automation and federated access to controlled environments.

As well as insourcing a best practice AWS implementation, our team have identified the value of software containerisation based on Docker and Kubernetes. The customer will require training and upskilling in containers and Kubernetes as they begin consuming and moving workloads onto the platform.

Sorry for the long winded explanation - but I wanted to give you all a good idea of the project. 

We require someone to start with us prior to the 5th July 2017 - if possible to be UK based consultant willing to travel to Germany.

Please contact me directly on DM or at <mailto:alex.jones@contino.io|alex.jones@contino.io>

Many thanks!! 
Alex

attachments.text: At Sky Betting & Gaming we don’t have team Teams we have Tribes. Each Tribe is made up of small, agile and autonomous squads who work collaboratively with a shared purpose. So whether you join our Bet Tribe, Early Careers Tribe or anything in between, you will work with a group of people with raw energy, natural talent, and the kind of spirit that helps us think big, act bold, and change the game. It all means that we’ve created the kind of workplace that wins awards such as a place on the prestigious list of Sunday Times 100 Best Companies to Work For. What you’ll do: You will develop, operate, and evolve the Bet Tribe’s next-generation platform, based on Kubernetes, enabling internal teams to evolving their software and services with the minimum of friction.  You will also help teams to use various services on the platform, including deployment pipelines, service discovery, monitoring and alerting tools etc.  How you’ll do it: Required: Experience of Docker in production Networking AWS Linux operations Git Jenkins or similar CI system Beneficial: Kubernetes or similar platforms • Prometheus, graphite, or similar for monitoring and alerting ElasticSearch or similar for log aggregation Operating high-scaled websites Multi-team development environment Regulated environments Consul or similar for service discovery  How we work: Our engineers work closely with colleagues in all positions, so a high level of interpersonal skill is important to us.   We are supporting squads running their apps in containers on Kubernetes.  This is a new platform for SB&G, so working with other teams to learn pros/cons etc is important. We use various agile techniques; you must be comfortable either working through tasks on your own, or collaborating with others. You will need to demonstrate good levels of skill in some of the following: Linux sysadmin, networking, containers, AWS, VMWare.   We expect candidates to be comfortable working in a highly technical environment, with various regulatory concerns.   We value previous experience developing and operating high-demand & high-availability environments.   Our ‘10% time’ policy means Friday afternoons are your time to remain at the top of your game.    . Based in Yorkshire, we have grown to become one of the UK’s leading online betting and gaming companies. A business driven by bleeding edge technology, that brings the excitement of sports betting, casino games, poker and bingo to over 200,000 customers a day & growing! It’s a workplace like no other, with a mission to make Betting & Gaming better. And we want you to be part of it. Our People Ambition is to attract & develop diverse & talented people to meet the current and future growth needs of SB&G. Together, our aim is to create the Best Digital Business to work at. Mon to Fri – Standard

text: If you like working on Kubernetes or even distributed systems in general, we are looking for engineers (full time/permanent)to join us at Kasten. We are an early-stage funded startup based in the Bay Area (sorry, no remote for now) and you can find out more about the positions at <http://careers.kasten.io/>. Feel free to apply using the site, message me here privately, or email <mailto:ntolia@kasten.io|ntolia@kasten.io> if you think you might be interested.
whoah that was some big wall of text :slightly_smiling_face:

Hi everyone!

We're looking for somebody in EU to help us respond to possible downtimes of our cluster + improve it by adding better monitoring/alerts, autoscaling, etc..

The reason we're looking for a sysadmin in EU is that half of our customers are there and we are located in San Francisco so if our app goes down when we sleep it's pretty bad for them. They also use our product 8-9h a day so downtimes are really not desirable and is a big problem for us. Enough to look for a freelance sysadmin :slightly_smiling_face:

Here's what I'm thinking you could help us in the first period with:

- Migrate us completely to helm (we've already done it with one our sites), but the main product is still using a combination of replication controllers/services. We want to use helm so that we can have an easier deployment of another staging cluster for example or do tenant isolation.
- Setup a monitoring/alerts for our services. Currently our stack is comprised of a uWSGI python server, flask-socketio, celery workers, rabbitmq cluster and 2 prostgres instances. The alerts should be a bit more based on the load of those services rather than simple up/down state.
- Setup autoscaling for our workers (web and celery) so that they scale according to traffic/rabbitmq available messages in certain queues. At first only k8s autoscaling, then we might launch additional nodes on the cluster too, but that's latter on and not a priority for now.

FYI: we're on GCP using their hosted k8s.

Once we've done all that we'd like to have somebody on pager duty during the day (8h). We're essentially looking to cover the european timezone as much as we can just in case there is something bad going on.

If you're interested send me an email: <mailto:alex@gorgias.io|alex@gorgias.io>
